fields.headline: Shark species threatened by humans
fields.bodyText: Endangered globally Scalloped hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini) Great hammerhead (Sphyrna mokarran) Widely distributed in coastal and continental shelf waters in warm-temperate and tropical seas. Meat is considered unpalatable for people so hammerheads are often "finned" – millions serve the Hong Kong markets each year. Giant devil rays (pictured) (Mobula mobular) These are found mainly in deep waters of the Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic, moving around in groups. They produce only a single pup at each pregnancy. Vulnerable globally Porbeagle shark ( Lamna nasus) These sharks are found in coastal and offshore temperate waters of the north Atlantic and also in the southern hemisphere. Sought for their high-quality meat and for fishmeal; also fished for their skins, liver oil, and fins. Shortfin mako (Isurus oxyrinchus) This coastal and oceanic shark is found in temperate and tropical seas around the world and scientists estimate that nearly a million makos a year end up in the Hong Kong shark-fin trade. Oceanic whitetip (pictured) (Carcharhinus longimanus) A slow-moving fish of tropical and temperate waters around the world, thought to have attacked more humans than all other shark species combined.
